title: What will the long-term interest rate be for South Africa (ZAF) in August 2017?
preds: A linear projection would gives something like 9.5%. I heard some bad political news re SA recently, leading me to take a pessimistic prior.

If the average monthly change over the last two years occurs, either positive or negative, from a starting point of 9.24,  the rate would move outside of the two most common brackets, either higher or lower. I want to invert my percentages so that less than 9.08 and between 9.37 and 9.52 are the most likely, but I guess this is the safe play. If I were more bold, I would suggest that it... nevermind. I'm changing it as I type. Not sure this is the best strategy, but i'm betting on volatility. About 40% of the time, the change will stay between the two middle bands, 60% of the time it's big enough to move to the outer parameters. I'm learning toward an increase. Who knows?
The trend is slightly rising and Zuma's squeak-by confidence vote makes the likelyhood of a next-month rate drop very small.
Because I want to try to understand global financial markets, this will force me to research.

I took a normal distribution around a mean 9.1 (lower than 9.24) because the 10y has been lower than 9.24 for most of august so far. I also reduced the std dev to a third of it's monthly value since we have about that much left till the end of the month.
I think GDP will stabilise, so there will be little pressure on long term rates to move in either direction.

Revised numbers to reflect approximate probability of lowering rates = 0.9, raising rates =0.1; redistributed previous point allocation accordingly.  Now new assumptions are:
1) the rate will go down (90% confidence)
2) 75.4% of the time, the rate moves 0.25% or less (based on historical data over the last 126 months)

Seems I'm less optimistic about the SA economy this month than most. In the last month Zuma survived a no confidence vote but he's also actively wrecking the economy so I don't think the outlook for the economy has improved this month. If anything I lean toward the forecast getting worse.

Looking at WSJ, Investing.com, Trading Economics, OECD, and reading the local newspapers. Trend is definitely down, and really we're looking at a tight possibility between the first 2 options.  Next official rate cut isn't until Sept after rate cut in July: “It is possible that the South African Reserve Bank will add to the unexpected interest rate cut seen in July with another rate cut in September‚” said FXTM analyst Jameel Ahmad." http://www.heraldlive.co.za/business/2017/08/23/jse-opens-firmer-easing-inflation-raises-hope-rate-cut/ SA already at junk status, business leaders definitely expect rate cuts, it's reasonable to expect the market is pricing this news in. https://www.moneyweb.co.za/news/economy/sa-economy-is-stuck/

Realizing my math didn't fit my previous logic & explanation, I revised the numbers to fit.
I'm assuming 2 key points:
1) the rate will go down
2) 75.4% of the time, the rate moves 0.25% or less (based on historical data over the last 126 months)

South African Reserve Bank (SARB) infrequently adjusts long term interest rates more than 25 basis points (0.25%) at one time--in fact only 31 out of 126 months has it moved by more than 0.25% (about 24.6%
 of the months)(https://data.oecd.org/interest/long-term-interest-rates.htm).
Based on this article, I think it will go down: https://www.moneyweb.co.za/news/economy/sa-economy-is-stuck/

Higher than June, lower than July.
https://tradingeconomics.com/south-africa/government-bond-yield

May 2016 9.29%
End of July 2017 9.24%
High From May 2016 through through July 2017 9.29%
Low 8.62%
Therefore, I mostly agree with @Smiley2
Comparison of previous years data and seasonal trends. Overall situation similar to 2016.
